In this paper, we demonstrate that incorporating turbine locations into downscaling with Gaussian Processes can generate valuable aggregate wind power predictions despite the low resolution of the CMIP6 climate models. This work is a first step towards multi-decadal turbine-location-aware wind power forecasting using global climate model output.

To mitigate climate change, wind energy will play a crucial role in future power supply (Barthelmie and Pryor, 2021). Efficient power planning should account for natural wind variability as well as climate change by incorporating climate projections into multi-decadal forecasts (e.g., Miao et al., 2023). However, these climate projections have two main shortcomings: their output resolutions are coarse due to the high complexity of climate models and are uncertain as they account for uncertain human behavior. To overcome the issue of coarse spatial resolution (usually ≥100km) of general circulation models (GCMs), downscaling techniques have been developed (e.g., Sun et al., 2024). Downscaling can increase the spatial and temporal resolution of GCMs using physical or statistical properties or machine learning (e.g., Langguth et al., 2024).

For multi-decadal wind power forecasts, where the goal is an accurate cumulative power prediction, Effenberger et al. (2023) have shown that a temporal resolution of 6 hours is usually sufficient. However, a high spatial resolution is often beneficial (e.g., Tamoffo et al., 2020). For CMIP6 (Eyring et al., 2016), the latest version of globally organized GCMs, no high-resolution regional model runs are available, in contrast to its predecessor CMIP5 (Jacob et al., 2020). Previous research revealed that CMIP6 and CMIP5 show differences regarding future wind resource projections for Europe (Carvalho et al., 2021), and other work has shown that CMIP6 has a better capability in simulating surface wind speeds over the Northern Hemisphere (Miao et al., 2023). Additionally, Jung and Schindler (2022) have shown that the highly unlikely worst-case climate model scenario (SSP585) is over-represented in current research (Davy et al., 2018). Hence, there is a need for realistic scenarios of CMIP6 for multi-decadal power forecasting.

Multi-decadal wind power forecasts are difficult to validate due to the lack of ground truth for the future (e.g., Risbey et al., 2021). Most renewable power research data is confidential, so it is common to use wind speeds or wind speeds cubed as a proxy for wind power (e.g., Jung and Schindler, 2020; Miao et al., 2023). Some research considers turbine locations for more realistic power predictions (e.g., Tobin et al., 2016; Jung and Schindler, 2020). Using CMIP6 data directly, we can account for the latest climate model updates. With Gaussian Processes (GPs), we include turbine locations into our power predictions and show that these are similar to ground truth power generation.

Our analysis reveals that taking turbine locations into account in multi-decadal wind power forecasting is even more important than the climate scenario. We describe our approach in Section 2, our results in Section 3, and discuss and conclude in Section 4 and Section 5.

2 Methods

Our general approach includes:

1. Estimating wind speeds at turbine locations
2. Extrapolating wind speeds to hub-height
3. Predicting the power output

We compare the wind speeds at turbine locations to predictions that do not involve locations and are based on gridded weather or climate datasets. We perform the same steps on these datasets but:

1. Use the wind speeds at grid points
2. Extrapolate wind speeds to the average hub-height
3. Compute the power output using the most common turbine across the dataset

Data

For our evaluation, we consider the gridded reanalysis dataset ERA5 (Hersbach et al., 2020) and the gridded climate dataset MPI-ESM1.2-HR (Müller et al., 2018) from CMIP6. We compare our predictions generated using these weather and climate datasets to aggregated transmission level power generation. The data setup is further described in Appendix A.
